p: Moringa oleifera is a genus of the fast-growing tropical deciduous plant of the Moringaceae family, with thick, tuberous roots, light green leaves and abundant flowering with elongated, pendulous fruits and seeds [ 1]. It is a native crop of northern India, although it is found in southwest Asia, southwest and northwest Africa and Madagascar. It has long been a part of traditional horticulture, used mainly for ornamental purposes in cities along the Pacific coast of Mexico [ 2], as well as plantations in Bolivia, Argentina and elsewhere in the world [ 3]. It has 13 known species, with Moringa oleifera, native to India, being one of the most studied and used for its nutritional, phytochemical and pharmacological properties. According to ayurvedic medicine (traditional and alternative medicine of India) [ 4], it is attributed properties for the treatment of some diseases, such as asthma, epilepsy, eye and skin diseases, fever and haemorrhoids [ 5, 6, 7]. In fact, it is a medicinal plant traditionally known in the approach to malnutrition and other diseases [ 8].
